page.title: 10CONSERVATION
page.content: While we were touring around the area we noticed that some farmers had been laying hedges.This is mostly done to Hawthorn and is a skill which is mainly caried out by older farmers and workers.First the hedge is cut and then narrow posts are knocked into the ground about 2m. apart.Next the main branches are chopped almost through and woven in and out of the posts.At the same time as this is done the farmer clears the ditches which is why this process is known as 'Hedging and Ditching'.The finished hedge should not need redoing for about 20 years providing it is trimmed.It is more secure and looks more attractive than fences or barbed wire.The hedge gives protection to birds and wildlife. Keeping the ditches clear helps to prevent pollution.
